name: Indiana Jones® and the Fate of Atlantis™
description: The Man With The Hat Is Back In His Greatest Adventure Yet! 1939 - The eve of World War II. Nazi agents are about to get their hands on a weapon more dangerous than the atom bomb. Only Indy can stop them before they unleash the deadly secret that sank Atlantis.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or Vista Processor: Any 2002 era PC or better Memory: 32 MB RAM Graphics: 2 MB - PCI Graphics Card DirectX®: Required for sound Hard Drive: 155 MB Sound: 16-bit sound card

reviews.review_text: Its old, i got it mostly because its one of those games i played when i was a kid. Its has a great story and i remember it well as one of my favorite point and click adventure games, right up there with the first Monkey Island game.

This is definitively a classic game you should play. At least if you are a fan of point&click and Indiana Jones.  Don't judge the graphics, the game is from the 90's.  I played it in window mode. But be warned, if you click outside and have an overlapping window there might be the chance you will not see that area when clicking back to the game. Clipping is computed differently ;-)  For such an old game the graphics are awesome. A lot of small easter eggs and funny scenes can be found. Sound is like it was back then.

I remember hearing about this game when it first came out and was upset I didn't own a computer at the time to play it. Thanks to Steam, I finally had the chance and brought back a lot of nostaglia for games of that time. What impressed me the most is that the story is excellent. This should have been the fourth film and I do consider it a 'hidden film' of the franchise. Voice acting is great as well. A landmark game and a very enjoyable one.

BUY IT! Awesome game back then. Saw it and decided to buy it again. Wow did this bring back memories from more than 14 years ago. Very fun puzzle solving, if you want to it can be eaiser (path of the fist), but path of the wits gave me a challenge. Overall challenging puzzles, great old humor, many lucas arts refernces, overall for a game released in 1992 at the time it was in the top 10 adventure games, back then. Be sure to check out others like sam and max hit the road, the dig, full throttle,etc. Definatly worth the price and then some!  I have the original and yes theirs programs like scumm vm to run it, but with that comes a lot of errors and hoops to jump through yes it is nice, but after so many headaches and frustration with grim fandango (save issue 5 hours in) im glad i got this. Yes i did have one issue it said script error, but every game has an issue everyonce in awhile and you save whenever you want so get over it even back then in dos with a capabile machine it still crashed. All in all ran fine except one error which i just went back in and loaded my save and worked 100% after that!

I owned both the original release on a 3.5 Floppy and the CD version. The steam version works wonders and plays as if i were playing it on my old 386 pc! Recommend playing and trying out all the differnt story variations which i was surpised there were so many even when 1st playing 24 years ago.
Better than Loom.

Yeah, it's not looking like games from today. But this game is one of the first I've played on PC... and I have memories of being stuck in the damn desert and of that damn balloon to lead... When you're only a child, it's marking you. Without that game, I wouldn't be playing adventure games or indie games like Ben Jordan, Chzo Mythos or Barn Runner.  As it's a very old game, you have that old interface with 'Push', 'Pull', 'Use', etc.. It's perhaps a weird way to play an adventure game now but it was the norm back then.  Anyway, I managed to get stuck in the first level when I remember clearly being at ease when I was a child.  The graphics are maybe pixelated but between libraries, islands, deserts and I don't know more because I stayed stuck in the desert like before and because I'm more aware of the multiple paths you can take now than before.  So, if you're in for good memories, the game is made for you.
So many memories.
What 'Kingdom of the Crystal Skull' should have been.
Good ol' classic.
Classic point and click...

'Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis' if by far one of the greatest adveture games every made. I played this game back in the day possibly 20+ play throughs as I loved the different paths you could take, not to mention it's INDIANA JONES, cmon!!! Everything about this game is great, if you like adventure point and click games, this should be of top play priority! I hope they remaster this game like they did 'Day of the Tentacle', I would buy it in a heart beat and play it all again!
Much better than what I have imagined.

Indy Solo and Fate of Atlantis is much like Wispa chocolate bar. In 1992 many people like Wispa and buy many chocolate bar. Over years more and more chocolate bar released so Wispa sells fall. One day sales so low that Wispa no longer available. Ebay then filled with 'last Wispa from vending machines' for large fee.  Steam then say 'We will sell Wispa again' which made people lick lips and claim they cannot wait...  I buy Wispa, and it look like a Wispa but taste I do not remember being same. I still eat Wispa, but think it is only okay. After Wispa I go back to buying Aero. Aero much better. I am not mad I waste money on Wispa as it made me like Aero more.  What I really want to eat is Spira whilst playing Curse of Monkey Island.
THIS GAME COMPLETELY SUCKS!!!
Old School Indiana jones... used to play this as a child
my favorite game from my childhood. Highly recommended if you like point and click games!
This game is really good, love it.

Love this game ever since I got it on floppy disc YEARS ago. Love the multible endings and the alternative paths you can take. The voice acting is not really 'needed', but cancel it out and its quite fun!

This is a damn fine old school adventure game. There's some really funny moments, in the spirit of the film series, and you actually have to think about some of the puzzles - this game doesn't patronise you. There are also different endings depending on which path you decide to take.
This is solely to hit that 'Nostalgia' button . One of the more challenging games i've ever played. A bit unforgiving, but never-the-less a really fun game.

This is one of my favorite point and click adventure games. It is very old and nostalgic for me. I bought it because I could not play my Win 95 CD on Win 7 or XP in any compatability mode. Steam version plays fine on Win 7 x64 and Win 10 x64.

For anyone that grew up on classic PC adventure games like Monkey Island and Maniac Mansion, this is another fantastic game to add to your collection. It's an oldie, but I highly recommend it. The puzzles and story still hold up very well to this day. Enjoy!
one of the best point and click adventure games, also see: Maniac Mansion: Day of the tentacle. be aware that the graphics are horrible by today's standards

So be quick, point and click adventure games aren't for everyone. But if you want a terrific detailed story to take you for a wild ride with some gimmicks, decent puzzles and a little attention to detail....this game is it.   This was the first game I ever owned as a child, and still the best in terms of story presentation as well as game progression. This game...shares among the top 10 best point and click adventures to exist.

One of the best point-and-click adventure games ever made. The graphics are kind of old by today's standards but the art is still beautiful. The story is great and is probably better than the movies. The puzzles are wide and varied but never too hard. There's also great replay value because there are 3 main paths to choose from that will take you to different places depending on your choice.

This is nice and cheap now, but I'd still wait on sales. Adventure game and all. Classic Indy story plus classic adventure game workings plus classic graphics and pixels equals quite a fun little package. Just one thing though, remember to save regularly - I crashed one time and I got too far into it that I couldn't get back to it within about two hours. I should really pick this back up again. It's a very fun little adventure game from the past! Just don't break the bank obtaining it.

The last time I played this game was when I was 4 years old and I really loved it. 11 years later I came across this game on Steam store. When I istalled it and started to play, I really moved by its 8-bit graphics and Indi' s voice. There is only one word that can describe this game: 'EPIC'

When you feel like you need a good dose of retro adventure games or want to feel like a pixellated treasure hunter with a whip, pick this one up. A classic that never gets old. Fun puzzles, Indiana Jones'ish dialogue and nazis!  An adventure game that never gets old. If you are a die-hard FPS-gamer, avoid this, it would be like giving pearls to pigs. You wouldn't appreciate this game as much as it deseves. All the rest, it is cheap, pick it up, sit back, start clicking and enjoy (and I suggest you to turn speak voices off).

A good ol' fashioned puzzle game with lots of variety and angles to the puzzles. I loved it as a kid and gave it a second chance recently and I gotta say it still holds upp. If you're a fan of a slow paced game with the one and only Dr. Indiana Jones, this is a game you will enjoy!

This game is pure genious! Be warned that it does show it's age just a bit. Occaisionally you'll have to click on things more than you would like to, but overall does not hold it back. I played this game as a kid, and somehow beat it. Im pretty sure i peaked at a walkthrough at least a few times on my road to atlantis this time around, but i highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of Indy or anyone who is a fan of oldschool point and click adventures.
So much nostalgia from playing it in the 90s. Glad it made it to the 21st century on steam.

Love this game! This is easily up there as one of, if not, the best lucasarts adventure games. I played this back on my 486 in both text and speech versions. A great game that you can play through three different ways. I've played through each way at least once. LOVE this game.

You play as Indiana Jones in a point-and-click style game. Need I really say more?  Okay, I will. Unless you feel any nostalgia for old point-and-click games like Putt-Putt or Pajama Sam, avoid this game. These kind of games will usually frustrate and some puzzle elements are insane with how specific they get. I think the way these games communicate with the player is off, because I find myself hitting a dead end sometimes for longer than I'd like in a point-and-click, and then suddenly I'll have that 'eurika!' moment and move on.. Maybe it's a limit of the genre, but I don't see too many leaps in this game. I'd still recommend if you like adverture games.
One of the LucasArts Classics.  It features full voice over and runs perfectly on a modern windows system.

One of the ultimate LucasArts classics from the golden age of adventure games. As with all LucasArts adventures of that era, it should to be preserved in a time capsule for all future generations to enjoy.

If you get to the uboat scene and the rudder is still locked, take it out of reverse. I can't seem to save the game, and the small window ♥♥♥♥ is kind of stupid... what the hell? Otherwise, a classic Lucas Arts game... who knew when I was a kid this ♥♥♥♥ was more real then I would have ever thought though.
Awesome story with multiple endings, marvelous music, great characters and exceptional puzzles. A must-play for any point-and-click lovers out there.
